qas.question: What product replaced LaserDisc in North America by the early 2000s?
Who chose LaserFisc for their Domesday Project in the mid-1980s?
What was the BBC Domesday Project?

answers.text: a school-based project to commemorate 900 years since the original Domesday Book in England

qas.question: Which country still exported players to North America until 2001?

context: By the early 2000s, LaserDisc was completely replaced by <a0_0>DVD<a0_0/> in the North American retail marketplace, as neither players nor software were then produced. Players were still exported to North America from Japan until the end of 2001. The format has retained some popularity among American collectors, and to a greater degree in <a3_0>Japan<a3_0/>, where the format was better supported and more prevalent during its life. In Europe, LaserDisc always remained an obscure format. It was chosen by the <a1_0>British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)<a1_0/> for the BBC Domesday Project in the mid-1980s, <a2_0>a school-based project to commemorate 900 years since the original Domesday Book in England<a2_0/>. From 1991 up until the early 2000s, the BBC also used LaserDisc technology to play out the channel idents.
